Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today, and I am the leader of the session.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket for the third time, and I know it’s my mom. She expects me to check in every evening, to tell her about my day, to answer her questions right away. It’s how we stay close, how I show her I care. But tonight, I’m sitting cross-legged at the front of the meditation hall, guiding our weekly session. As the leader, I’m supposed to be fully present, to set an example of mindfulness and calm for everyone here. My mind keeps drifting to my phone, to the messages piling up, to the worry I know my mom feels when I don’t reply. I try to focus on my breath, on the gentle rhythm of the group’s breathing, but guilt tugs at me. I want to honor my commitment to this practice, to the people who look to me for guidance, but I also want to be the attentive child my parents expect. The two roles pull at me from opposite directions, and I sit in the quiet room, heart pounding, unsure which expectation I should meet first.
